awd_titl_txt: HCC: Large: Collaborative Research:  Beyond Flat Images:  Acquiring, Processing, and Fabricating Visually Rich Material Appearance
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite revolutionary advances in how images are recorded, manipulated, and reproduced, our ability to re-create the visual experience remains remarkably limited.  Few realistic computer models exist for the characteristic appearance of natural materials such as marble, wood, coral, or skin, or man-made ones such as color-shifting automotive paints.  Digitizing and creating realistic images of these substances involves reproducing their interaction with light:  the way light is reflected from surfaces, or scattered and absorbed within the materials.  Full reproducibility also involves "printing" a material as a real, physical object that modulates the light around us. However, it is currently impossible to output complex appearance the way we print color on a paper with fixed gloss, or create shapes using a 3D printer. This project encompasses a comprehensive, collaborative research agenda in computer graphics and related areas, to develop an end-to-end framework for acquiring, representing, and fabricating complex appearance, as well as to understand how it is perceived by the human visual system.

The enabling technical idea of the project is to treat materials as thin three-dimensional volumes populated with general scattering sites. This is a radical departure from the hitherto standard approach in computer graphics, which has studied materials purely as surfaces.  The volumetric representation subsumes and generalizes the diverse set of conventional representations that currently exist in graphics, including surface-based notions such as bidirectional reflectance (BRDF), spatially varying BRDF, and subsurface scattering distributions (BSSRDF).  Moreover, it enables fundamentally improved approaches to efficient yet general acquisition, fast and realistic rendering, and fabrication of objects exhibiting phenomena beyond simple surface reflectance and spatially homogeneous subsurface scattering.

por.por_cntn:
In this document, we discuss the portion of this collaborative grant covered by professors Lawrence and Barnes.

Professor Lawrence's research focused on computer graphics techniques in two areas. In the first area, Professor Lawrence focused on accurate acquisition, representation, and efficient rendering of complex computer graphics materials. This research allows for materials to be realistically depicted even if they have scratches, glints, or unusual reflectivity or surface polishing patterns. Such materials include shoes, Christmas ornaments, shiny floors, scratches in silverware, water, and metallic objects. Professor Lawrence's research also focused on ensuring that such materials can be rendered efficiently by computers and manipulated by designers. These techniques automatically discover and simplify mathematical expressions so that the large quantities of data involved can be reduced to a tractable amount.

The large quantities of data produced from this research and other similar research also motivated the professors' research on scalable and high throughput processing of visual information. Professor Lawrence developed an open-source software framework (called HIPI) for high throughput image processing. Professor Barnes continued work in a similar direction, by focusing on whether approximations can be used to make image processing more efficient. Professor Barnes also investigated how programs that manipulate visual information that are written in computer languages that are typically inefficient can be automatically accelerated.
The broader social impacts of this work include the involvement of women computer scientists in the above research, the potential for improvement of material depiction in computer graphics that could be used in e.g. Web commerce, and the potential for decreased power consumption, improved performance, and decreased costs needed for computer graphics programs.
